steps.text: Study materials for Food Manufacturing, Processing and Storage Pest Control certification are in 'A Guide for Private and Commercial Applicators: Applying Pesticides Correctly'.
Pass the general standards exam.
Study this manual and Arkansas Pest Control Law for Food Manufacturing, Processing and Storage Pest Control certification.
Pass the exam based on this manual and Arkansas Pest Control Law.
Obtain study materials from Arkansas State Plant Board.
Get additional information from University of Arkansas Cooperative Extension, pesticide labels, and manufacturers.
Check pesticide information for currency.
Use pesticides safely and follow label directions.
Integrate various pest control methods.
Construct a well-built building.
Implement preventive design and maintenance.
Establish daily pest management programs.
Record-keep for the pest management program.
Address pests from surrounding areas and incoming materials.
Maintain short grass and trim shrubs.
Pave access to building.
Ensure proper drainage around the building.
Create an 18- to 24-inch gravel strip around the foundation.
Install night-lights at least 30 feet away from doors.
Seal wall materials like concrete, brick, or tile.
Make hollow panel-type walls well-sealed.
Ensure roofs are smooth and free of standing water.
Install pitch and gravel or corrugated metal roofs if necessary.
Use few windows, preferably with transparent glass.
Choose metal doors that fit tightly.
Install air curtains at large doors to prevent pest entry.
Install dust-tight fixtures for good lighting.
Provide electrical and plumbing services for easy access and cleaning.
Make control panels insect-proof.
Equipment should be roomy and accessible for cleaning.
Equipment should be raised at least six inches off the floor or sealed to it.
Eliminate litter, waste, and uncut grass.
Explore other non-chemical management options.
Implement pesticide management options.
Pave dusty roads.
Maintain lawns.
Ensure proper drainage.
Position lighting away from buildings.
Reduce bird harborage.
Reduce outside food spillage.
Use rodent, insect, and bird traps.
Maintain housekeeping.
Implement pest monitoring programs (e.g., pheromone traps).
Maintain bait stations for rodents.
Use insecticidal baits and approved insecticides near breeding sites for insects.
Use chemical repellents and avicides where appropriate for birds.
Rodent-proof all openings.
Screen windows.
Eliminate cracks, crevices, and ledges.
Locate equipment off the floor or sealed to it.
Keep all areas free of loose materials.
Clean structures and equipment frequently.
Use electrified grids inside for insect attraction.
Inspect all incoming vehicles and materials.
Store materials away from walls for inspection access.
Use rodent traps near doors.
Map the locations of rodent traps.
Use air curtains at doors.
Use deterrents for birds on roosting sites.
Use rodent bait stations where policy permits (Pesticide Management).
Implement a detailed monitoring program (Preventive Maintenance).
Implement a total facility IPM program (Preventive Maintenance).
Use rodent traps near doors if needed.
Ensure proper sanitation.
Use space treatments as appropriate.
Use spot treatments as appropriate.
Use crack and crevice treatments as appropriate.
Use contact treatments as appropriate.
Identify packaging areas.
Implement pest management procedures in packaging areas.
Identify finished products warehouse.
Apply management requirements in finished products warehouse.
Form an inspection committee.
Include highest company official as chairman and all department heads.
Support the program with personnel from all levels.
Review existing activities and compile a list of deficiencies.
Wear identifiable uniforms and carry necessary tools for inspections.
Conduct thorough inspections, looking in new places and recording all defects completely and specifically.
Distribute notes to department heads for immediate action.
Correct defects immediately.
Meet at the end of an inspection cycle to review notes, address uncorrected items, and assign realistic correction dates.
Inspect obscure places using a flashlight.
Observe suspect stock on a flat surface.
Inspect areas most likely to produce results.
Consider periodic inspections by an outside firm.
Require an 18-inch space between pallets and warehouse walls for inspections and rodent prevention.
Create a written inspection procedure for incoming raw products.
Check vehicles and products during raw product receiving.
Record problems on a form.
Maintain housekeeping standards.
Implement a pallet-cleaning program.
Follow stock storage specifications.
Use a reliable stock rotation method.
Quickly remove spills and trash.
Employ Integrated Pest Management (IPM) approach for commodity protection.
Utilize natural enemies, cultural management, temperature, sanitation, and pesticides in control measures.
Determine potential losses and costs of control to decide on action.
Determine the regulation factor for storability.
Identify the specific factors regulating storability: moisture content, temperature, pest access, and time.
Determine suitable temperature range for insects and molds.
Maintain temperature between 65°F and 95°F.
Inspect all incoming materials.
Focus on high-risk foods.
Design buildings to minimize entry points.
Perform visual inspection.
Check for open packages and poor sanitation.
Inspect areas near lights.
Use pheromones as chemical attractants in traps.
Utilize food attractants to draw various species into traps.
Determine trap placement based on time of year and temperature profiles.
Place one trap per 4,000-5,000 square feet in high-risk areas.
Examine trends in trap catches over time to modify management practices and reduce populations.
Inspect bagged commodities using pheromone-baited traps.
Identify pests by examining caught insects.
Determine the extent of a problem based on trap results.
Evaluate treatment method effectiveness using trap data.
Identify common insect pests in raw grain.
Identify common insect pests in processed food.
Match trap type to environment (dusty vs. clean, hot vs. cold).
Use pitfall traps or deflecting dust traps in dusty areas.
Place traps on outer perimeter of a facility.
Intercept or lure pests to prevent indoor infestations.
Determine number of traps based on quality assurance standards and goal.
Place a wide grid of traps (one per 100,000 cubic feet).
If pests are detected, adjust trap placement or add more.
Look for increases in numbers from one period to the next.
Monitor and inspect using pheromone traps, glue boards, and visual inspections.
Implement structural modifications.
Use cold storage at 50°F.
Place proper lighting.
Introduce beneficial insects.
Use timed pyrethrin dispensers and pheromone traps for bulk seed storage.
Perform routine fumigation and empty bin treatments.
Control perimeter with weeds and insecticides.
Use ULD treatments based on pheromone trap thresholds in warehouses.
Fumigate with proper safety measures in warehouses.
Implement rodent control program using outdoor bait stations, rodenticides, and structural exclusion.
Install netting for bird control.
Use sticky repellents for bird control.
Apply avicides for bird control.
Close doors as part of bird control.
Consider limitations of pheromone traps for insect control.
Read the label on the pesticide container.
Ensure use is consistent with labeling.
Identify food, food processing facilities, nonfood areas, and food areas.
Determine types of residual applications for broad surfaces in food-handling establishments.
Apply insecticide to non-food areas.
Apply small amounts of insecticide into cracks, crevices, expansion joints, and voids.
Follow permitted residual application in food areas.
Understand pesticide regulations at the national level.
Identify the regulatory body for pesticide applications in Arkansas.
Determine if pesticide used on a food product has a tolerance or is exempt.
Check regulatory body responsible for enforcing tolerances.
Identify if food product contains unapproved pesticide or residue above tolerance level.
Destroy the adulterated food product.
Check pesticide labels for approved sites.
Apply pesticides only to sites listed on the label.
Obtain USDA-approved list of pesticides for federally inspected meat plants from federal inspector.
Do not use residuals in production areas where the product is exposed or where they might be carried in.
Use residuals only as a crack and crevice treatment in sealed production areas.
Assess safety responsibilities.
Review label and MSDS.
Conduct a facility survey.
Understand beetles and moths life cycle.
Identify if organism is a moth or beetle.
Determine presence or absence of legs on the back half of the body.
Identify adult feeding habits.
Identify the type of moth: Almond Moth or Indianmeal Moth.
Inspect the appearance of the forewings for brown-gray coloration (Almond Moth) or no specific description (Indianmeal Moth).
Examine the larvae for dirty white coloration (Almond Moth).
Identify the type of moth: Forewings are gray near the body and reddish at the tip.
Determine larvae characteristics: They leave a silken thread (webbing) on food surfaces.
Identify the specific type of moth: Mediterranean Flour Moth has pale gray wings with wavy black markings and larvae spin silken threads.
Determine food preferences: Larvae feed on a wide range of products like flour, cornmeal, seeds, nuts, and pet food.
Identify mealmoth by its light brown forewings with dark patches and white larvae with a black head.
Inspect damp or spoiled grain for presence of mealmoths.
Inspect incoming goods for moths.
Remove infested food and dust.
Heat treat grains at 140°F for one hour.
Apply residual insecticides.
Use space sprays.
Perform fumigation.
Identify the type of beetle.
Determine if it's a Cigarette Beetle, Drugstore Beetle, or Confused Flour Beetle.
Identify the type of grain beetle.
Determine if the beetle can fly.
Identify presence of Foreign Grain Beetle.
Check for signs of mold or mildew.
Identify presence of Rusty Grain Beetle.
Assess moisture conditions.
Identify presence of Spider Beetles.
Identify the type of beetle present: Warehouse Beetle or Dermestid Beetles.
Inspect the area where the beetles are active: dark, damp areas in a warehouse.
Identify signs of cockroach infestation: cast skins, egg cases, and musty odor.
Inspect areas where cockroaches are known to hide for physical evidence.
Identify the type of cockroach: German, American, Oriental, or Brown-banded.
Determine the preferred habitat based on the cockroach's description.
Control for cockroaches using sanitation.
Use crack and crevice or spot treatments with residual pesticides.
Supplement control with dusts and contact sprays.
Control flies through sanitation and removal of breeding sites.
Identify the type of pest: ants or bees and wasps.
For ants, treat the nest with direct treatment, barrier sprays, or baits.
For bees and wasps, treat nests at night using sprays or dusts.
Wear protective clothing when controlling bees and wasps.
Lower humidity for Booklice control.
Implement sanitation for Booklice.
Control Silverfish and Firebrats in damp areas.
Control Silverfish in hot, dry situations (Firebrats).
Manage lighting to reduce Cricket entry.
Identify soil-dwelling predators such as ground beetles.
Remove decaying vegetation and moisture sources near foundations to control sowbugs and pillbugs.
Understand rat and mouse behavior for effective control.
Identify rat and mouse senses: touch, smell, taste, hearing, and poor colorblind vision.
Identify fresh rat droppings.
Determine soft and dark texture.
Identify old droppings.
Look for cleared paths outdoors or greasy runways indoors.
Search for dark, greasy marks from the rodent's body along runways.
Inspect areas where rats prefer to burrow, such as earth banks or under concrete.
Check for tracks in dust or tracking patches.
Inspect for urine fluorescence under blacklight.
Implement sanitation and habitat modification.
Seal all openings larger than 1/4 inch for mice.
Seal all openings larger than 1/2 inch for rats.
Use rodent-resistant materials like hardware cloth, sheet metal, and concrete.
Pay attention to doors, windows, vents, drainpipes, foundations, and utility lines.
Track toxic dust using 'Tracking Powders'.
Place the powders in runways.
Rodents ingest the powder while grooming.
Select a proper bait.
Choose anticoagulants for multiple feedings or single-dose non-anticoagulants.
Offer unpoisoned bait for several days to overcome shyness.
Place tamper-proof bait stations every 10 feet for mice and 20 feet for rats along walls and runways.
Use cereal grains as common baits.
Place traps along walls, in dark corners, and behind objects.
Use many traps, placed close together.
Secure bait to the trap.
Choose a good bait such as peanut butter, raisins, nutmeats, or bacon.
Place rodent glue boards if using.
Clean the Compressed Air Sprayer after each use.
Check gaskets and valves regularly.
Never leave the Compressed Air Sprayer pressurized when unattended.
Identify the type of nozzle required: solid stream or fan.
Choose appropriate dusting tool based on the location and type of dust to be applied.
Keep Space Treating Equipment clean and dry.
Use aerosols for quick knockdown of flying insects.
Create fine particles (aerosols, fogs, mists) with Space Treating Equipment.
Use high concentrations of insecticide in fine droplets at reduced rates (Ultra Low Dosage).
Apply ULD with specialized equipment.
Wear respirators as indicated on the label.
Use filters for particulates.
Use sorbent cartridges/canisters for vapors/gases.
Choose chemical cartridge respirators for low concentrations.
Use gas masks (canisters) for higher concentrations and fumigants.
Supply clean air from an external source or a tank.
Ensure respirators are approved by MSHA and NIOSH.
Ensure a proper fit.
Perform daily negative and positive pressure checks.
Prevent beards from interfering with a tight seal.
Wash respirators regularly.
Store respirators in a clean, protected place.

constraints.text: The applicator must be aware of federal and state regulations.
Requires support from upper management and all department heads.
Effective vehicle inspection program is essential.
Legal requirement for a written inspection procedure in raw product receiving.
Follow the economic threshold concept for taking action.
Consider the different moisture requirements for various pests.
Temperatures outside the range of 65°F to 95°F are unfavorable for insects and molds.
Avoid rapid temperature drops.
Focus on oldest, high-risk foods.
Maintain good sanitation and temperature control.
* Lights attract stored product insects.
Visual inspection helps identify infestations.
Determine number of traps based on quality assurance standards and goal before placing them.
If pests are detected, adjust trap placement or add more to the suspect area.
Adhere to regulations for food area pesticide application.
Food product with unapproved pesticide or residue above tolerance level must be destroyed.
Only apply pesticides to approved sites as indicated on the label.
Pesticides used in federally inspected meat plants must be on a USDA-approved list.
Residuals cannot be used in production areas where the product is exposed or where they might be carried in.
Residuals can be used only as a crack and crevice treatment in sealed production areas.
Ensure safety of workers, facility employees, and food product.
Check the location of the infestation: dried fruits, nuts, pet foods, and candies.
* The red flour beetle can fly, while the confused cannot.
High moisture conditions present.
Beetles found in grain or related products.
Check for signs of infestation before entering the area.
Avoid touching or consuming contaminated food and surfaces.
* Rodents cannot be used where Tracking Powders might contaminate food.
Most Tracking Powders are Restricted Use pesticides.
Offer unpoisoned bait for several days before using acute toxicants.
Place bait stations along walls and runways every 10 feet for mice and 20 feet for rats.
Use ULD with specialized equipment and wear respirators to avoid inhalation hazards.
Wear respirators as indicated on the label, especially in enclosed spaces.
Respirators must be approved by MSHA and NIOSH.
Proper fit is essential.
